docs.lead_paragraph: When the notice came in December that his company's health insurance premiums were going up 22 percent, Jonathan South knew what he had to do. Mr. South, the office manager for a small Manhattan company, dropped the plan with Cigna Healthcare, one that allowed employees to go to doctors out of the network and would now have cost the company $241 per employee each month, and signed up for a plain vanilla health maintenance plan offered by Aetna, at a cost of $179 a month.

headline.main: Health Insurance Costs Rise, Hitting Small Business Hard

docs.abstract: American businesses, and in many cases employees, are facing some of steepest price increases for health insurance in almost 10 years as nation's insurers struggle through period of consolidation and falling profits; small businesses are feeling brunt of increases--leading to tougher decisions over whether to absorb higher costs, pass them on to employees or not offer benefits at all; while increases are more or less same nationwide, they are especially painful in New York, which has nation's most stringent form of practice known as community rating in which prices for businesses with fewer than 50 employees are set strictly by geographic area; experts worry that increases will worsen problem of uninsured, whose numbers in New York are well above national average; 19 percent of New York State residents under 65 were uninsured in 1998 and 28 percent uninsured in New York City; nationally, 17.6 percent of those under 65 lacked insurance; insurance rates for companies with more than 100 employees rose about 6 percent on average nationwide in January 1999, with small businesses seeing increases in range of 10 to 13 percent; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: SADIE ZHENZHEN ALPERSON delicately speared a baked ziti with one tine of her fork and with agonizing care fitted it into the narrow O of her mouth. She chewed, swallowed and barked: ''Bread. With but-ter.'' Her mother, Myra Alperson, asked, ''What do you say, Sadie?''
docs.abstract: Myra Alperson and the three-year-old daughter she adopted in China in 1996 are a happy twosome on Manhattan's Upper West Side, even though Ms Alperson must struggle to make ends meet; there are a surprisingly large number of such families in Manhattan, owing to supply of abandoned Chinese girls and the demand of women whose age, income and marital status make it difficult for them to adopt American babies; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: AS a journalist, Carol Abaya covered an aborted Communist coup in Indonesia, the seizure of power by Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines and race riots in Paterson. But none of this was as tough as stepping in to care for her elderly parents.

headline.main: A Survival Course for the Sandwich Generation

docs.abstract: Interview with Carol Abaya on her work helping midlife adults, many with growing families, cope with carrying for aging parents; tips on parent care; photo (M)
docs.snippet: AS a journalist, Carol Abaya covered an aborted Communist coup in Indonesia, the seizure of power by Ferdinand Marcos in the Philippines and race riots in Paterson.    But none of this was as tough as stepping in to care for her elderly parents.

docs.lead_paragraph: PEOPLE just tuning in to Washington over the past year of sex, pizza and judicial racing stripes could be forgiven for wondering: Is Government usually this diverting? Of course, it's all in the eye of the beholder. But don't decide for yourself until after you've sampled the one-minute House floor speeches of Representative James A. Traficant Jr., Democrat of Ohio.

headline.main: Word for Word/Representative James A. Traficant Jr.; Burping Cows and Space Toilets. Beam Me Up, Mr. Speaker!

docs.abstract: Word for Word column quotes some of Repr James A Traficant Jr's special one-minute addresses before House, in which he takes aim at government inanities, and often concludes with 'beam me up'; photo (S)
docs.snippet: PEOPLE just tuning in to Washington over the past year of sex, pizza and judicial racing stripes could be forgiven for wondering: Is Government usually this diverting?    Of course, it's all in the eye of the beholder. But don't decide for yourself...

docs.lead_paragraph: At first glance, it is hard to tell a baby is there. Then the clues come from following the tubes that blow air into the baby's tiny nostrils. Another tube carries nutrients into a vein. The boy has a crop of black hair. He is barely a foot long. He is curled up on a soft pillow and strapped in a cloth bumper, dotted with hearts, to keep his arms and legs in the same flexed position they were in in the womb. As he sleeps beneath a radiant warmer in the dark and quiet room, machines track his skin temperature, heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen level and other vital measurements. Two Beanie Babies lie nearby. One toy serves an extra function: the Beanie's weight holds the air tubes in place.

headline.main: For Surviving Octuplets, Progress Comes in Ounces

docs.abstract: Births of octuplets by Nkem Chukwu in Houston, Texas, renewed debate about fertility drugs and enormous medical and human costs they have brought on; smallest baby, girl named Odera, weighed 10.3 ounces and died on Dec 26; caring for seven surviving babies requires round-the-clock efforts by dozens of health care professionals at Texas Children's Hospital; Iyke Louis Udobi is father; parents are American citizens born in Nigeria; doctors say babies have 95 percent chance of surviving to their expected discharge in late March; photo (M)
docs.snippet: At first glance, it is hard to tell a baby is there.    Then the clues come from following the tubes that blow air into the baby's tiny nostrils. Another tube carries nutrients into a vein. The boy has a crop of black hair. He is barely a foot long....

docs.lead_paragraph: BEAMING with pride of ownership, Jose and Paula Lora stood before their dark-red, split-level home in Teaneck, N.J., last weekend, a long way from the city of Santiago in the Dominican Republic and -- if not geographically, at least in their minds -- nearly as far from the cramped Bronx rental apartments in which they had lived since arriving in the United States a decade ago. The house cost $170,000 and, after several years of saving, the Loras managed to make a down payment of $25,000. ''It has four bedrooms, a study and a small basement for the kids to watch TV,'' Mr. Lora said, ''you know, to do the mess, the games, the toys.'' Jorge is 9, and Ruth is 8.

headline.main: Finding a Home Inside the Golden Door

docs.abstract: Immigrants seeking housing face various difficulties in dealing with intricacies of real estate in New York area; some succeed in their quest for decent housing, some do not; they confront language barrier, jarring cultural differences, complexity of rental and mortgage-acquisition system, lack of credit history, lack of banking services in their communities, incomes off the books, racial discrimination, even being cheated, sometimes by their own countrymen; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Maybe it was fitting that a tumultuous event in academia seemed to turn on a metaphor. Shortly before the Modern Language Association's annual meeting, Elaine Showalter, the president, informed her charges -- full-time professors, part-time professors and graduate students in English and foreign languages -- that they were on a sinking ship, the Titanic to be precise. Now there is a bitter dispute about the lifeboats. Ms. Showalter's assessment was based on the M.L.A.'s survey of the nearly 2,200 graduate students who got their degrees in English, foreign languages, comparative literature, linguistics and classics in the 1996-97 academic year. Only 33 percent of those in English found tenure-track jobs within a year of finishing. Those in foreign languages and comparative literature had slightly better luck (about 40 percent got tenure-track jobs), while those in linguistics and classics did worse (30 percent). The figures are not only very close to the survival rates on the Titanic, but also to what graduate students in other humanities face.

headline.main: Professors or Proletarians? A Test for Downtrodden Academics

docs.abstract: Modern Language Assn convention in San Francisco discusses plight of graduate students and young doctorate holders in English and the humanities who are unable to find tenure-track jobs; president Elaine Showalter suggests scholars stop complaining and jump into other fields, particularly business; others say only hope is to organize to protest university practice of using cheap part-time labor rather than hiring more professors; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Maybe it was fitting that a tumultuous event in academia seemed to turn on a metaphor. Shortly before the Modern Language Association's annual meeting, Elaine Showalter, the president, informed her charges -- full-time professors, part-time...

docs.lead_paragraph: Medicare officials said today that they would pay private health plans more for patients who were sick and less for patients who were healthy. The new technique represents a major change in Federal health policy. It will penalize health maintenance organizations that avoid sick people and reward those that enroll such patients.

headline.main: Medicare to Pay Health Plans Bonuses for Sicker Patients

docs.abstract: Medicare will pay private health plans more for patients who are sick and less for those who are healthy; will also penalize HMOs that avoid sick people and reward those enrolling ill patients; major policy shift will take effect gradually over five years; officials charge many HMOs have fattened profits by cherry-picking healthier seniors (S)
docs.snippet: Medicare officials said today that they would pay private health plans more for patients who were sick and less for patients who were healthy.    The new technique represents a major change in Federal health policy. It will penalize health...

docs.lead_paragraph: The head of the New York State branch of the Latin Kings street gang, who had claimed to be leading members away from violence and drug dealing to self-improvement and community advocacy, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to traffic in heroin and cocaine. As more than 50 followers and supporters watched in Federal District Court in Brooklyn, Antonio Fernandez, 32, a Brooklyn man known as King Tone, admitted the crime in a plea deal under which he is expected to be sentenced to 12 1/2 to 15 1/2 years in prison. That is about half the prison time he would have faced had he been convicted at a trial.

headline.main: Gang Leader Pleads Guilty To Conspiracy In Drug Case

docs.abstract: Antonio Fernandez, Latin Kings leader in New York who claimed to be leading gang members away from crime, pleads guilty in Federal court to trafficking in heroin and cocaine; 32-year-old Fernandez will be sentenced to up to 15 1/2 years in prison, less than half sentence he could have faced if case had gone to trial; photo (S)
docs.snippet: The head of the New York State branch of the Latin Kings street gang, who had claimed to be leading members away from violence and drug dealing to self-improvement and community advocacy, pleaded guilty yesterday to conspiring to traffic in heroin...

docs.lead_paragraph: For his startling State of the City speech yesterday, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani shed the formal podium, dropped his cumbersome chart routine and laid out a long list of ideas -- some aimed at his new national fan club, others an effort to cement his entry in New York City history. At the top of this list is a grand plan for the warehouse and storage area on Manhattan's West Side. Replacing today's bleak landscape near the Jacob Javits Convention Center, the Mayor would build, as he put it, ''the most famous sports facility in the world.'' This facility would include a domed football stadium that would fit in the area just south of the Javits Center. He suggested moving Madison Square Garden to an area just east of the center. Then the No. 7 subway line would be extended and rerouted south, along existing rail lines, to add transportation that would serve the Javits Center, the stadium and the Garden.

headline.main: A Football Dome for the City

docs.abstract: Editorial on New York City Mayor Giuliani's 'startling' State of City address, noting in particular his proposal for 'most famous sports facility in the world' to replace bleak landscape of Manhattan's West Side near Jacob Javits Convention Center; comments on some of Giuliani's other proposals, noting that his partisan rhetoric was tempered with effort by Giuliani to show his better, less abrasive side
